\texttt{~~~\%nodes~n~and~m~position}\\\texttt{~~~n~=~1;}\\\texttt{~~~m~=~6;}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%find~the~size~of~the~matrix~L}\\\texttt{~~~lenL~=~length(L);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%swap~nodes~n~and~m~to~the~1st~and~2nd~position~in~the~Laplacian~matrix}\\\texttt{~~~swap~=~{[}n,~m,~1:(n-1),~(n+1):(m-1),~(m+1):lenL{]};}\\\texttt{~~~L~=~L(swap,~swap);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%compute~matrix~S~which~is~the~voltage~to~current~map~(Schur's~complement).}\\\texttt{~~~A~=~L((1:2),~(1:2));}\\\texttt{~~~B~=~L((3:lenL),~(1:2));}\\\texttt{~~~C~=~L((3:lenL),~(3:lenL));}\\\texttt{~~~S~=~A~-~(B}= \texttt{~~~\%nodes~n~and~m~position}\\\texttt{~~~n~=~1;}\\\texttt{~~~m~=~6;}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%find~the~size~of~the~matrix~L}\\\texttt{~~~lenL~=~length(L);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%swap~nodes~n~and~m~to~the~1st~and~2nd~position~in~the~Laplacian~matrix}\\\texttt{~~~swap~=~{[}n,~m,~1:(n-1),~(n+1):(m-1),~(m+1):lenL{]};}\\\texttt{~~~L~=~L(swap,~swap);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%compute~matrix~S~which~is~the~voltage~to~current~map~(Schur's~complement).}\\\texttt{~~~A~=~L((1:2),~(1:2));}\\\texttt{~~~B~=~L((3:lenL),~(1:2));}\\\texttt{~~~C~=~L((3:lenL),~(3:lenL));}\\\texttt{~~~S~=~A~-~(B}$^{\prime}$\texttt{~*~C}\textsuperscript{\texttt{(}}\texttt{-1)~*~B);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%finds~the~effective~resistance~which~is~the~first~entry~of~S.}\\\texttt{~~~r~=~1/S(1,1);} =\texttt{~*~C}\textsuperscript{\texttt{(}}\texttt{-1)~*~B);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%finds~the~effective~resistance~which~is~the~first~entry~of~S.}\\\texttt{~~~r~=~1/S(1,1);}You could run this for the 2 different Laplacian matrices to find the

question: 4 (e)
sols_html:
To find the effective resistance between two nodes, you would have to swap the 1st and sixth columns to the 1 and 2 positions inside the Laplacian matrix. You would then break up this Laplacian matrix into a block matrix

\[\begin{aligned} L = \begin{bmatrix} A & B^{T} \\ B & C \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

where \(A\) will be a 2x2 matrix.

You would then find the voltage to current map (A.K.A Schur\(^{\prime}\)s complement), matrix S whose equation is

\[\begin{aligned} S = A - B^{T} C^{-1} B\end{aligned}\]

Then, after solving for S, the effective resistance would be the reciprocal of the 1st entry of matrix S.

MATLAB CODE:

   %nodes n and m position
   n = 1;
   m = 6;
   
   %find the size of the matrix L
   lenL = length(L);
   
   %swap nodes n and m to the 1st and 2nd position in the Laplacian matrix
   swap = [n, m, 1:(n-1), (n+1):(m-1), (m+1):lenL];
   L = L(swap, swap);
   
   %compute matrix S which is the voltage to current map (Schur’s complement).
   A = L((1:2), (1:2));
   B = L((3:lenL), (1:2));
   C = L((3:lenL), (3:lenL));
   S = A - (B\(^{\prime}\) * C(-1) * B);
   
   %finds the effective resistance which is the first entry of S.
   r = 1/S(1,1);

You could run this for the 2 different Laplacian matrices to find the effective resistance for each and compare them to confirm the conjecture is correct.
statement_html:
Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this diagram:

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges (resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers. Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let D be the incidence matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges) and let L be the Laplacian.

(e) It seems reasonable to conjecture that the effective resistance between nodes 1 and 6 would remain unchanged if removed the resistors between 2 and 3, 3 and 4, 4 and 5, 5 and 2. Explain how you could use MATLAB/Octave to test this conjecture. Assume that L has been defined in MATLAB/Octave.

Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this
diagram:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH307/April_2012/MATH307_April_2012_Question_04.png}
\end{description}

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges
(resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers.
Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let \emph{D} be the incidence
matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges)
and let \emph{L} be the Laplacian.

\textbf{(e)} It seems reasonable to conjecture that the effective
resistance between nodes 1 and 6 would remain unchanged if removed the
resistors between 2 and 3, 3 and 4, 4 and 5, 5 and 2. Explain how you
could use MATLAB/Octave to test this conjecture. Assume that \emph{L}
has been defined in MATLAB/Octave.
statement_raw:
Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this diagram:

:[[File:MATH307 April 2012 Question 04.png|300px]]

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges (resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers. Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let ''D'' be the incidence matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges) and let ''L'' be the Laplacian.

'''(e)''' It seems reasonable to conjecture that the effective resistance between nodes 1 and 6 would remain unchanged if removed the resistors between 2 and 3, 3 and 4, 4 and 5, 5 and 2. Explain how you could use MATLAB/Octave to test this conjecture. Assume that ''L'' has been defined in MATLAB/Octave.
